Desmospora profundinema is a species of bacteria that belongs to the phylum Bacteroidetes. It is a Gram-negative, obligately anaerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium. Desmospora profundinema was first isolated from deep-sea sediment samples collected from the Pacific Ocean.

This species is characterized by its rod-shaped cell morphology and its ability to grow at high hydrostatic pressures, typically found in deep-sea environments. Desmospora profundinema is able to ferment various carbohydrates, including glucose, fructose, and sucrose, as well as some amino acids, to produce acetate, propionate, and other organic acids as the main end products of its metabolism.

The genome of Desmospora profundinema has been sequenced, revealing insights into its adaptations to the deep-sea environment, such as the presence of genes involved in the synthesis of compatible solutes and the regulation of gene expression under high-pressure conditions.

This bacterium is of interest to researchers studying the diversity and ecological roles of microorganisms in deep-sea ecosystems, as well as their potential biotechnological applications, particularly in the development of biocatalysts and bioremediation strategies for deep-sea environments.
